questions.question: What is the first rule of the four (Jeff Cooper) firearms safety rules?

options.text: A.  Never point a gun at something you don't want to shoot.
B.  Always run away from guns.
C.  'All guns are always loaded.'
D.  Keep your finger off the trigger until you're ready to destroy.
E.  Call your lawyer before you handle any gun.

questions.question: What is the second rule of the four (Jeff Cooper) firearms safety rules?

options.text: A.  Be certain of your target.
B.  Unload all guns first thing.
C.  Keep your finger off the trigger until your sights are on target and you're ready to fire.
D.  Follow the orders of the safety officer.
E.  Never let the muzzle cover anything you don't intend to destroy.

questions.question: What is the third fule of the four (Jeff Cooper) firearms safety rules?

options.text: A.  Keep your finger off the trigger until your sights are on target and you're ready to fire.
B.  Be certain of your target and what's behind it and in front of it.
C.  Be aware of local range rules and regulations.
D.  Follow relevant laws, both federal and local.
E.  Never let the muzzle cover anything you don't intend to destroy.

questions.question: What is the fourth rule of the four (Jeff Cooper) firearms safety rules?

options.text: A.  Know where all pets and children are before you fire.
B.  Ensure guns are loaded before firing.
C.  Keep your finger off the trigger until your sights are on target and you're ready to fire.
D.  Be certain of your target and what's behind it and in front of it.
E.  Be certain what will stop your bullet before you fire it.

questions.question: When holstering your handgun, where should your trigger finger be?

options.text: A.  Inside the trigger guard.
B.  Indexed and outside the trigger guard.
C.  On the front of the trigger guard.
D.  Curled inward toward the palm.
E.  Inside your ear canal.

questions.question: When reholstering your handgun, how fast should you go?

options.text: A.  Go as fast as you can.
B.  Best to keep your gun out; wolves travel in packs!
C.  There's no need to reholster quickly, take your time
D.  You get bonus points for reholstering quicker than everyone else.
E.  Just lay the gun down on the ground.

questions.question: Someone hands you a firearm in a gun store.  What should you do first?

options.text: A.  Handling the gun safely, ensure the gun is unloaded and clear.
B.  Lock the slide to the rear or open the bolt.
C.  Drop the magazine, if there is one.
D.  Open the cylinder and press the extractor rod.
E.  Ask that person, 'Is it loaded?'

questions.question: You're clearing a semi-auto handgun.  What are the first two steps?

options.text: A.  Rack the slide once and drop the magazine.
B.  Drop the magazine and lock the slide to the rear.
C.  Tap the magazine and lock the slide to the rear.
D.  Drop the magazine, rack the slide, and re-insert the magazine.
E.  Remove the magazine and look down the muzzle to see if there's a bullet in the chamber.

questions.question: You have a loaded double action revolver with the hammer cocked.  How can you make the gun safe?

options.text: A.  Put your off-side thumb infront of the hammer and press the trigger, then unload as usual.
B.  Put your strong-side thumb on the hammer and press the trigger to lower it gently onto the loaded chamber, then unload as usual.
C.  Just leave the hammber cocked back and unload as usual.
D.  Go ahead and press the trigger, the transfer bar will prevent ignition.  Then unload as usual.
E.  Never unload a double action revolver; it's already safe.

questions.question: Your 12-year-old son's friend shows him his father's gun.  What should your son do?

options.text: A.  Call the police.
B.  Call you at work.
C.  Take the gun and demonstrate correct gun handling with the gun.
D.  Explain the Jeff Cooper safety rules to his friend and show him this online quiz.
E.  Politely ask his friend to not handle any guns without an adult present and leave immediately if the friend doesn't comply.
